titleStmt.title: A Table of the words of Artlate∣ly deuised by Ned Browne and his associates, to Crosbite the old Phrases vsed in the manner of Conny-catching.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: A Table of the words of Artlate∣ly deuised by Ned Browne and his associates, to Crosbite the old Phrases vsed in the manner of Conny-catching.

monogr.title: The blacke bookes messenger : Laying open the life and death of Ned Browne one of the most notable cutpurses, crosbiters, and conny-catchers, that euer liued in England. Heerein hee telleth verie pleasantly in his owne person such strange prancks and monstrous villanies b him and his consorte performed, as the like was yet neuer heard of in any of the former bookes of conny-catching. By R.G
monogr.author: Greene, Robert, 1558?-1592

div.head: A Table of the words of Artlately deuised by Ned Browne and his associates, to Crosbite the old Phrases vsed in the manner of Conny-catching.

list.item: HE that drawes the fish to the bait, the Beater.
The Tauerne where they goe, the Bush.
The foole that is caught, the Bird.
Connycatching to be called, B • tfowling.
The wine to be called, the Shrap.
The Cards to be called, the Li • twigs.
The fetching in a Conny, beating the bush
The good Asse if he be woone, stooping to the Lure.
If he keepe aloofe, a H • ggard.
The verser in conny-catching is called, the Retriuer.
And the Barnacle, the pot hunter.
